intro: Ageratina crassiceps, commonly known as the thick-stemmed blueweed, is a flowering plant native to the Caribbean and parts of Central and South America. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads that resemble small clusters of tiny flowers. The plant features sturdy, branching stems covered in dense, short hairs, and its leaves are typically lance-shaped with a rough texture. Its flowers are blue to purple in color, blooming in late summer to early autumn, and it produces small, dry fruits called achenes. Ageratina crassiceps is often found in open, disturbed habitats such as roadsides and dry forests.
